title: 109_s2654
content: The "Protection of Young Consumers Act of 2006" is also known as the Protection of Young Consumers from Prescreened Credit Offers Act. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to include provisions for consumers aged 21 or older, with an option for those at least 18 years old to authorize inclusion in consumer reporting agency lists. Additionally, there is an amendment for young consumers to opt-in for certain credit reporting activities. The Fair Credit Reporting Act is amended to allow consumers aged 18 to 20 to opt-in for inclusion in consumer reporting agency lists for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by them. Consumers aged 18 to 20 can opt-in to be included in consumer reporting agency lists for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by them by submitting a signed notice of election form. The election is effective until the consumer's 21st birthday. Consumers aged 18 to 20 can opt-in to be included in consumer reporting agency lists for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by them by submitting a signed notice of election form. The election is effective until the consumer's 21st birthday and applies to all agency affiliates. An election does not limit the applicability of this subsection to individuals aged 21 or older, who can choose to be excluded from such lists. Consumers aged 18 to 20 can choose to be included in consumer reporting agency lists for credit or insurance transactions not initiated by them until their 21st birthday. Individuals aged 21 or older can opt-out of such lists. Title IV of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new section promoting youth financial literacy. The Youth Financial Education Act, also known as Title IV, aims to promote financial literacy among young adults. Despite the importance of financial knowledge, many high school graduates lack basic skills in managing personal finances. A survey found that on average, 12th graders answered only 52 percent of financial literacy questions correctly. The National Endowment for Financial Education High School Financial Planning Program shows that 10 hours of classroom instruction can significantly improve teens' money management skills. Despite recognition of the importance of financial education in K-12 education, only 7 states required a personal finance course for high school graduation by 2004. Personal finance education is crucial for youth before graduating from high school. Teacher training is essential for achieving financial literacy among students. It helps prepare them for the workforce, financial independence, and improves their life skills. Financial education covers topics like income, taxes, money management, investment, spending, and personal savings. The teaching of personal finance should be encouraged at all levels of our Nation's educational system, from kindergarten through grade 12, as the consumers and investors of tomorrow are in our schools today. "State grant program for personal finance education from kindergarten to grade 12." The Secretary can award grants to State educational agencies for youth financial education programs in elementary and secondary schools. State agencies must submit an approved plan to receive grants, detailing fund usage and program support. The Secretary allocates funds to States based on student populations in kindergarten through grade 12. States must coordinate grant programs with other relevant programs and evaluate program performance. The Secretary allocates funds to States based on student populations in kindergarten through grade 12. States with approved plans will receive a grant of at least $500,000. Funds will be reallocated to States without approved plans or whose plans have been disapproved. Grant funds must be used to provide funds to local educational agencies. The grant funds allocated by the Secretary are to be used by State educational agencies to support financial education programs for students in K-12, teacher training, and program evaluation. A maximum of 4 percent of the grant can be used for administrative costs. State educational agencies receiving grants must use no more than 4 percent for administrative costs. They must submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing the programs supported and the results of monitoring and evaluation. "State educational agencies receiving grants must use no more than 4 percent for administrative costs and submit annual reports to the Secretary detailing programs and results of monitoring and evaluation. SEC. 4403 establishes a clearinghouse." The Secretary will grant funds to an eligible entity with experience in financial education to establish a national clearinghouse for instructional materials and information on financial education programs. The eligible entity must be a national nonprofit organization with a record of cataloging youth financial literacy materials and providing support services to promote youth financial literacy. The Clearinghouse, funded by the Secretary on a competitive basis for 5 years, will maintain instructional materials on financial education for schools and disseminate information to States and localities. The Clearinghouse, funded by the Secretary, will disseminate instructional materials and provide technical assistance for financial education programs in schools. The chief executive officer will consult with the Department of the Treasury and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Each Federal agency must submit to the Clearinghouse. The Clearinghouse, funded by the Secretary, will disseminate instructional materials and provide technical assistance for financial education programs in schools. Each Federal agency developing financial educational programs must submit information and materials to the Clearinghouse. The Clearinghouse will comply with copyright laws in its operations. The Clearinghouse, funded by the Secretary, will disseminate instructional materials and provide technical assistance for financial education programs in schools. Each Federal agency developing financial educational programs must submit information and materials to the Clearinghouse. The Clearinghouse will comply with copyright laws in its operations. SEC. 4404 requires evaluation and reporting. The Secretary will develop performance measures to evaluate programs assisted under sections 4402 and 4403. Using these measures, programs will be evaluated for performance, effectiveness, best practices, and potential replication for technical assistance. Additionally, a report will be required for each fiscal year with appropriations under section 4407(a). The Secretary will transmit a report to Congress detailing the implementation of this part, including the evaluation results and description of programs supported under section 4402. SEC. 4405 defines financial education as activities supervised by qualified teachers to teach students economic principles, personal finance management, and consumer responsibility. A qualified teacher is defined as someone with a valid teaching certification or recognized by the State educational agency. SEC. 4406 prohibits certain actions. SEC. 4406 prohibits Federal officers from controlling a State or school's instructional content for funding eligibility. SEC. 4407 authorizes appropriations. Authorization of funds for fiscal years 2007 through 2011 is set at $100,000,000 annually. The Secretary can allocate 2-5% for Clearinghouse and up to $200,000 for evaluation purposes. Administrative costs are limited to subsections (a) and (b) of section 4404. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended by inserting a new item after section 4304 in the table of contents. "PART D--PROMOTING YOUTH FINANCIAL LITERACY" "Sec. 4401-4407 outlines the provisions for promoting youth financial literacy. The Comptroller General will conduct an annual study on the effectiveness of programs under part D of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965, submitting reports to Congress annually." Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2007 and the following 4 years is provided to carry out this section.
